quizDescription: Test your knowledge across multiple categories. Select up to 3 questions from each category for a customized challenge!

categories.name: Science
categories.description: Questions about physics, chemistry, biology and other scientific fields

questions.text: What is the chemical symbol for gold?
questions.explanation: Gold's chemical symbol Au comes from the Latin word 'aurum', meaning gold.

questions.text: What is the hardest natural substance on Earth?
questions.explanation: Diamonds are the hardest naturally occurring substance according to the Mohs scale of mineral hardness.

questions.text: Which planet has the most moons?
questions.explanation: Saturn has the most confirmed moons with 83 confirmed moons.

questions.text: What is the speed of light in a vacuum?
questions.explanation: The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792 kilometers per second, often rounded to 300,000 km/s.

questions.text: Which of these elements has the highest atomic number?
questions.explanation: Uranium has an atomic number of 92, which is higher than lead (82), platinum (78), and mercury (80).

categories.name: History
categories.description: Questions about important historical events and figures

questions.text: In which year did World War II end?
questions.explanation: World War II ended in 1945 with the surrender of Japan after the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

questions.text: Who was the first President of the United States?
questions.explanation: George Washington served as the first President of the United States from 1789 to 1797.

questions.text: The ancient city of Machu Picchu was built by which civilization?
questions.explanation: Machu Picchu was built by the Inca Empire in the 15th century.

questions.text: Which year did the Berlin Wall fall?
questions.explanation: The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, marking a symbolic end to the Cold War division of Europe.

questions.text: Who was the Egyptian queen who allied with Roman leaders Julius Caesar and Mark Antony?
questions.explanation: Cleopatra VII was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt and formed political alliances with both Julius Caesar and Mark Antony.

categories.name: Geography
categories.description: Questions about countries, capitals, landmarks, and geographical features

questions.text: What is the capital of Japan?
questions.explanation: Tokyo is the capital and largest city of Japan.

questions.text: Which is the longest river in the world?
questions.explanation: The Nile River is generally considered the longest river in the world at approximately 6,650 kilometers (4,130 miles).

questions.text: Which country has the largest area?
questions.explanation: Russia is the largest country by area, spanning approximately 17.1 million square kilometers (6.6 million square miles).

questions.text: Which mountain range separates Europe and Asia?
questions.explanation: The Ural Mountains form part of the conventional boundary between the continents of Europe and Asia.

questions.text: Which country is home to Angkor Wat?
questions.explanation: Angkor Wat is a temple complex in Cambodia and is the largest religious monument in the world.

categories.name: Literature
categories.description: Questions about famous books, authors, and literary works

questions.text: Who wrote 'Pride and Prejudice'?
questions.explanation: Pride and Prejudice was written by Jane Austen and first published in 1813.

questions.text: Who is the author of the 'Harry Potter' series?
questions.explanation: J.K. Rowling is the author of the Harry Potter series, which began with 'Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone' published in 1997.

questions.text: Which play features the character Hamlet?
questions.explanation: Hamlet is a tragedy written by William Shakespeare, featuring the character Prince Hamlet of Denmark.

questions.text: Who wrote '1984'?
questions.explanation: 1984 is a dystopian social science fiction novel by George Orwell, published in 1949.

questions.text: Which of these works was written by Gabriel García Márquez?

options.text: Love in the Time of Cholera

questions.explanation: Love in the Time of Cholera was written by Colombian Nobel Prize winner Gabriel García Márquez and published in 1985.

categories.name: Technology
categories.description: Questions about computers, software, the internet, and technological innovations

questions.text: Who is often called the founder of Microsoft?
questions.explanation: Bill Gates co-founded Microsoft with Paul Allen in 1975.

questions.text: Which programming language is known for its use in web browsers?
questions.explanation: JavaScript is primarily known as the scripting language for web pages and is used in browsers worldwide.

questions.text: What does CPU stand for?
questions.explanation: CPU stands for Central Processing Unit, which is the primary component of a computer that processes instructions.

questions.text: Which company developed the iPhone?
questions.explanation: The iPhone was developed by Apple Inc. and was first released in 2007.

questions.text: What technology is used for making decentralized digital currency like Bitcoin?
questions.explanation: Blockchain is a decentralized, distributed ledger technology that records transactions across many computers.
